H0.text: Eruption is close is indicated by a continuous string of earthquakes at a volcano.

H1.text: Extinction is close indicates that a continuous string of earthquakes shows a volcano is near extinction.

H2.text: It is cooling down is what a continuous string of earthquakes indicates about a volcano.

H3.text: It is heating up indicates that a continuous string of earthquakes means a volcano is heating up.

A4.text: Seismic activity occurs as a precursor to most large eruptions.

A5.text: Rarely, because of complex interactions, it may appear to settle just before an eruption.

A6.text: These earthquakes tend to occur in swarms as opposed to mainshockâ€“aftershock sequences.

A7.text: This does not mean that always this activity will give sufficient warning of an eruption.

A8.text: Increasing seismic activity is a good indicator of increasing eruption risk, especially if long-period events become dominant and episodes of harmonic tremor appear.

A9.text: The occurrence of long-period events were then used to predict the 1989 eruption of Mount Redoubt in Alaska and the 1993 eruption of Galeras in Colombia.
